results.title: Theatre: getting your act together
results.brief_description: Presents a behind-the-scenes look at the theatre and the roles of the playwright, director, actor and theatre production staff. Designed to promote students’ interest in the theatre and to provide them with an insight into the workings of two professional theatre companies - The Melbourne Theatre Company and Sydney’s King O’Malley Theatre Company. The program is divided into five sections: 1 What is theatre? 2 The playwright in society. 3 In rehearsal. 4 The performance. 5 Theatre in society.

results.title: Théâtre Optique
results.brief_description: In 1892, two years after developing the praxinoscope theatre, Charles-Émile Reynaud debuted his grandest invention – the Théâtre Optique – in Paris. This device projected moving pictures that had been hand-painted onto flexible, coloured, regularly perforated strips of gelatine crystalloid.

constellations_primary.name: Technology and work
constellations_primary.description: How does the godfather of animation and sprocket technology connect to Jane Fonda workout videos and a Jesus biopic?

results.description:
Charles-Émile Reynaud rarely sat still. In 1892, two years after developing the praxinoscope theatre, he debuted his grandest invention – the Théâtre Optique – in Paris. This device projected moving pictures that had been hand-painted onto flexible, coloured, regularly perforated strips of gelatine crystalloid, and it even featured synced sound via silver inlays, an electromagnet and an electric noise generator.

For its time, Reynaud’s device was the pinnacle of moving image projection and greatly influenced the Lumière brothers, who joined over 500,000 visitors to Reynaud’s performances. These 15-minute shows were predecessors to cartoons and let large gatherings watch projections together. They were some of the world’s first mass-viewing experiences.
description_for_label:
Charles-Émile Reynaud rarely sat still. In 1892, two years after developing the praxinoscope theatre, he debuted his grandest invention – the Théâtre Optique – in Paris. This device projected moving pictures that had been hand-painted onto flexible, coloured, regularly perforated strips of gelatine crystalloid, and it even featured synced sound via silver inlays, an electromagnet and an electric noise generator.

For its time, Reynaud’s device was the pinnacle of moving image projection and greatly influenced the Lumière brothers, who joined over 500,000 visitors to Reynaud’s performances. These 15-minute shows were predecessors to cartoons and let large gatherings watch projections together. They were some of the world’s first mass-viewing experiences.

results.title: Theater of the absurd: Luigi Pirandello: Six characters in search of an author
results.creator_credit: Films for the Humanities, Harold Mantell and Ken Frankel
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the drama”.
An abridged presentation in English of Pirandello’s play in which six characters seek to exchange their fixed, frozen form in art for the uncertainty of life, to distinguish between dramatic reality and dramatic illusion, between acting and artifice in real life, and between reality and truth. Narrated by Joseph Heller.

results.title: The Zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to one of the world’s largest and most modern zoos, the Chicago Zoological Park. Animals are observed in areas simulating their natural habitat. Features polar and kodiak bears, lions, tigers, kanagaroos, baboons and a variety of familiar and not so familiar animals.

results.title: The Zertigo Diamond Caper
results.brief_description: The police are baffled when the world’s largest diamond is stolen from its top security museum display. Jeffrey, a 12 year old blind boy is present when the crime is committed. His mother, a museum administrator, is one of only three people with access to the diamond through the voice-print-security system, and she’s the chief suspect. To complicate matters, Jeffrey’s divorced father is assigned to the case and ignores Jeffrey’s crime-solving efforts. It’s up to Jeffrey to piece together the puzzling clues.

results.title: The Zebra in your stable
results.brief_description: Why do zebras have stripes? Why do broncos buck? How do horses manage to stand so still for hours? The horse. Its power and grace has stirred the human emotions for hundreds of years. From its exotic Arabian relatives to the show performances of the perfect thoroughbred, man’s love for the horse is undying. But how well does man understand these equine creatures? In this captivating documentary, Desmond Morris shows that underneath the stripes, the wild exteriors and the tutored perfection, different breeds are much the same animal. A horse lovers delight, this unique video journeys from the African plains to the wild Navaho desert, exploring the nature and habits of all breeds of horse, showing the wild animal that lurks beneath the domesticity.

results.title: The Yugoslav experiment
results.brief_description: This film uses newsreels and interviews to trace the history of Yugoslavia and shows the present day situation, (of 1977). Emphasis is placed on the Yugoslav economy, the agricultural and industrial systems, tourism and education.

results.title: The Yucatec Maya: a case study in marriage and the family
results.creator_credit: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Prompted by a desire to rediscover the extended family pattern of existence of his grandparents, anthropologist Hubert L. Smith lived for some time in the small Mexican village of Chican where the people still followed a traditional pattern of growing corn, beans and squash in jungle clearings, whilst being aware of the modern world nearby. In particular he studied one family and their attempt at sending the two youngest children away to school. The program successfully shows the reasons for the extended family in this environment and how it may have to change. Narrated by David Carradine.
